utterances: It's not the kind of frat boy atmosphere I think people who think of one, they think from men's magazine.
You know, we're all very attuned to each other.
And everything that's done with enough sensitivity that I think it comes across.
There is no high brow.
There is no low brow.
There is only what we like.
And style and design is about that for us.
And thankfully, it's about that for Kanye, too.
Well, Peter Ruben is feature editor for Complex magazine.
And he joined us right here at our NPR bureau in Culver City, California.
Thank you so much.
Thank you.
The current issue of Complex magazine is available on newsstands now.
The United States has sanctions in place against more than two dozen countries and more than 7,000 companies, individuals and groups.
That is more than in any other time in U.S.
history, which seems like a good moment to ask the question, do sanctions actually work?
Stacey Vanek Smith and Cardiff Garcia, hosts of The Indicator from Planet Money, tried to find out.
Some of the sanctions the U.S.
has in place have really deep roots.
U.S.
sanctions against Cuba go back decades.
Some sanctions are really new.
Our latest sanctions against Iran went into effect just a few weeks ago.
Dan Drezner is a professor of international politics at the Tufts University School of Law and Diplomacy.
He's also the author of ""The Sanctions Paradox."" Dan says there are four key elements that can help sanctions be successful.
The first is - and I know this sounds banal - but that your demand is actually specific.
Dan says the current demands on Iran by the Trump administration seemed really unclear and really broad when he read them.
And he says this might make U.S.
sanctions against Iran much less likely to be effective.
The second rule of sanctions, Dan says, is that it helps if you're allies in some way with the country that you are sanctioning or at least, that you do some business with that country.
Otherwise, there's just not as much to lose because the ties aren't that strong.
So that's rule no. 2 - sanction your friends...
(Laughter).
...Or at least your frenemies, I guess.
Always sanction your...
Yeah.
...Frenemies.
Rule no. 3 - go after the money not the products.
So in many ways, if you try to impose a trade embargo of some kind, as I said, you're incentivizing black market activity.
And local traders are going to be perfectly happy to bust sanctions.
And they're not really going to worry about, let's say, losing access to the U.S.
market.

On the other hand, when you talk about financial sanctions, the dollar is such an important part of global capital markets that any reputable bank does not want to risk running afoul of the United States Treasury.
Rule no. 4 - make sure you've got a lot of other countries on board.
All those frenemies.
Yeah.
Exactly, because otherwise, the country being sanctioned can more easily find other ways to do business or even worse, they might start to cut you out of the system.
We're sort of approaching the point where if you step back, it seems that we're using this tool an awful lot.
And here, the concern becomes you're going to start incentivizing actors can find alternatives to the dollar.
But there's another downside, one that's a lot more human.
Branko Milanovic is an economist at the City University of New York, and he specializes in inequality.
Blanket sanctions, I think, actually, are fundamentally wrong.
They punish people who, actually, don't have any influence or very small influence on what the government does.
Branko worries that something similar will happen in Iran, where people were already protesting a lack of drinking water and problems affording basic food staples.
Of course, there's also this idea that sanctions will make conditions in a country really bad and cause the population to revolt and overthrow the leadership.
But that can backfire, says Branko.
No. But we need to have better diplomacy…
Ron, thank you.
You know, Labor Day is usually considered the big kickoff day for campaigns, but usually that refers to the Labor Day in the same year as the election, right?
Exactly.
And here we are 14 months out from the election.

But, you know, in a sense there is a special significance to the Labor Day milestone in the odd numbered year before the election, and that is that, in the Republican Party at least, the frontrunner at that point gets the nomination.
And this goes back 40 years and usually that's what that means.
If you got it out front in September, a year before the election, that nomination is going to be years.
And that would be really good news for Rudy Giuliani under normal circumstances.
But these are not normal circumstances.
He's only at about 28 percent of the national polls on average.
That's not terribly dominant.

And while he might be the candidate with the strongest chance in the general election, he's the most Democrat-like of all the candidates, and that's going to cause him a lot of trouble with some of his Republican rivals in the months ahead.
Well, and he's about to get a bit more company.
This Thursday, senator-turned ""Law & Order"" regular Fred Thompson will finally into the race officially.
Ron, can you tell us a little bit about how he'll make his foray into the race?
And considering that we've been hearing Thompson talk about this for so long, will anyone even care now that he's making it official?

He's going to start it out on Jay Leno on Wednesday night, which I think is interesting, because all the other Republican candidates are going to be partaking in a national televised debate on Fox News.
They're actually in the hurly-burly of this.
They're in the fray.
And Fred Thompson is still kind of out there on his own schedule and kind of on his own level and he's talking to Jay Leno, and he's maybe talking…
Which conveniently gets him out of the debate.
Exactly.
And he has conveniently stayed out of all these debates all summer long.
And maybe that's been smart.
Maybe the other candidates are going a little stale.

But right at this point an awful lot of Republicans have become impatient with Fred Thompson and they are going to care that he's getting in the race, especially the ones that haven't committed to Rudy or one of the other candidates.
They're still looking for somebody they think is going to be the person to lead the party out of the wilderness it's in at the moment.
Ron, over the weekend, several of the top Democrats in the race vowed not to campaign in Florida, Michigan, any other states who try to move their primaries up.
How will that decision affect their campaigns?
I'm not sure it's going to make a huge difference with respect to Michigan because not that many candidates were spending that much time there or planning to spend that much there.
But Florida is another animal.
Any Democrat who wants to be president feels they must win Florida in 2008.
So it's going to be an enormous temptation to go in there for private fundraisers.
And maybe have a little bit of a lingering appearance at the airport when you first get there.

And maybe have a little bit of shirttail following along behind the candidate while the candidates in Florida just to get a little bit of media buzz going without, of course, officially campaigning in Florida.
Well.
in this day and age, too, with so many of the campaigns being waged on the Internet, is it possible to campaign in these places without actually going there?
That's a good point.
Both national television and of course the Internet will reach wherever.
And so the candidates can keep in a sense their footprints out of the state of Florida but still have their, if you will, virtual prints all over the state.
Of course, the other big political event over the weekend - Idaho Senator Larry Craig stepped down.
What does future look like for the state of Idaho?
It's a pretty Republican place.
Any chance of a Democrat filling in his seat?
Not really.
I don't think there's a realistic prospect of that.
The only one would have arisen if Larry Craig had tried to stick it out and tried to actually keep his seat and run for reelection in 2008.
As it is, we expect the Lieutenant Governor Jim Risch to get this nomination.
But either he or perhaps Dirk Kempthorne, former governor and former senator, now the secretary of interior, could hold that seat probably pretty easily in 2008.
The Republicans have a lot of other problems going into next year's election season in the Senate, so they didn't want to have another one in Idaho.
NPR senior Washington editor Ron Elving.
Thanks so much, Ron.
Thank you, Alex.
Now to politics in Minnesota, where if you're a Democrat, you don't run for any office until you've stopped at Schneider's Drugstore.
Once a month, pharmacist Tom Sengupta turns his store into a neighborhood town hall.
For 20 years, candidates from Paul Wellstone to Walter Mondale have pass through Schneider's to talk politics.
Reporter Michael May dropped in for a visit.
It's clear from the start this isn't your typical campaign photo op.
Those are the issues that I'm having to deal with.
Unidentified Man #1: Oh, I understand.
You know, oh but…
And - listen.
At this humble drugstore, Democratic candidates can hash out complex public policy goals with a tight-knit group of grassroots intellectuals, a sort of liberal tribe of elders.
